title: French (1731) Bible de Saurin Commentry Discours historiques critiques théologiques et moraux (Vol 1 3)
title_vernacular: Bible de Saurin (1731) Commentaire, Discours historiques, critiques, théologiques et moraux (Vol 1-3)
description:
The "Discours historiques, critiques, théologiques et moraux sur les événements les plus mémorables du Vieux et du Nouveau Testament" (Historical, Critical, Theological, and Moral Discourses on the Most Memorable Events of the Old and New Testament) is a collection of sermons written by Jacques Saurin, a prominent French Protestant preacher of the late 17th and early 18th centuries. Born in 1677 in Nîmes, France, Saurin and his family fled to Geneva after the Revocation of the Edict of Nantes (1685), which led to the persecution of French Protestants (Huguenots). There, he studied theology and philosophy before becoming a pastor.

Originally published between 1720 and 1728, this work provides a detailed analysis of biblical narratives, combining historical context, theological reflection, moral teaching, and critical interpretation. The 1731 edition, spanning three volumes, offers a comprehensive collection of Saurin’s sermons, aiming to educate and inspire readers by drawing moral and spiritual lessons from both the Old and New Testaments.

Saurin’s approach is characterized by intellectual depth, eloquence, and a commitment to Reformed Protestant theology. His work was widely appreciated for making biblical teachings accessible, relevant, and engaging for his audience.
